name: 7.0 Release
body:
Enhancements:
* Support for JDK 17
* ListenableFutureTask and SettableListenableFuture were re-implemented to provide better compatibility and performance (#256)

Major API version change, breaking changes include:
* Minimum JVM version updated to 11

Deprecation's removed:
* `ListenableFutureTask` no longer supports a recurring or repeating mode of operation.  Because of that the `boolean` to define the mode is no longer accepted.  If you previously were passing a `false` for this argument it can be simply removed.  If recurring execution is needed this can be hacked in easily (and is done within the library in our compatibility layer).
* One of `ConfigurableThreadFactory`'s constructors has been removed, supplying an additional `null` argument at the end will match 6.X's functionality.
* The above constructor change also was done to `ThreadReferencingThreadFactory`.  Supplying an additional `null` argument at the end will match 6.X's functionality.
* `SameThreadSubmitterExecutor` can no longer be constructed.  Internal optimizations require the use of `SameThreadSubmitterExecutor.instance()`
* In `Profiler` invocations of `dump` where specifying if individual threads should be included have been removed.  Now an additional argument must be specified for the minimum number of times a stack had to be witnessed before it was reported, allowing an even more concise output.  Specifying an argument of `1` at the end will match 6.X's functionality.
* `UnsafeAccess` was removed to comply with JDK 17 support

The above is summarized in our migration guide: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/wiki/Major-version-migration-guide#6x---7x

Feel free to join our Zulip chat or file an issue if you need help with migration

name: 6.7 Release
body: 6.7 Release is primarily focused around API changes in `ListenableFutureTask`.  In 7.0 the ability to have a recurring `ListenableFutureTask` is removed.  For that reason the constructor has been changed to no longer accept a boolean for this recurring state.  Assuming a `false` was previously provided this argument can now simply be removed.

name: 6.6 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Added to `StatisticsUtils` `getMax` and `getMin` implementations in order to find the extreme values in a collection of `Number`'s
* `FutureUtils.makeFirstResultFuture` permutation added where errors are ignored.
* `FutureUtils.makeResultListFuture` wont throw an `IllegalStateException` if a dependent future is canceled.  Because it needs the results (unless errors are ignored), this is still a fatal condition.  However the resulting future will now indicate this state instead of having the Exception thrown.

name: 6.5 Release
body:
* The constructor for `SameThreadSubmitterExecutor` has been deprecated.  This was meant to be done earlier, instead `SameThreadSubmitterExecutor.instance()` should be used.

* `ReschedulingOperation` performance improvements by to looping instead of immediately executing if it was signaled while running.  This provides a couple improvements:
  - No need to incur the overhead of queuing and cross thread communication to execute immediately
  - When a SameThreadSubmitterExecutor is used this will avoid a possible stack overflow

* `ConfigurableThreadFactory` now has the ability to add a listener to be provided threads as they are created.  This can be useful for debugging or other monitoring code which needs to know about threads related to specific pools.  Within the threadly library `ControlledThreadProfiler` is a perfect example of how this can be leveraged.

name: 6.4 Release
body:
This release includes:
* Bug fix to `OrderedExecutorLimiter` where canceled `ListenableFuture`'s returned by it could result in a `NullPointerException` when sorting the queue.
* Implemented issue #270 so that idle ForkJoinPool threads are identified and summarized in output

name: 6.3 Release
body:
Improvements included in this release:
* New constructor in `Profiler` to control how the dump is produced for the ListenableFuture result in a timed `start`.  This can be useful when using the timed start and needing to produce large dumps or otherwise concerned about the performance impacts.
* `OrderedExecutorLimiter` was extended to allow the limits to be adjusted at runtime just like the `ExecutorLimiter` can.  If you extend `ExecutorLimiter` in your application please read the commit notes: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/a21152e029d36343755e2acc0eca9c33ed261682

name: 6.2 Release
body:
Improvements included in this release:
* Added `OrderedExecutorLimiter`.  This limiter provides the first way to provide a task ordering besides FIFO.
* Minor logic simplifications in workerIdle loop in PriorityScheduler with reduced burdens to check for pool shutdown (now deferring only to the max pool size).
* Fix for `SingleThreadScheduler.prestartExecutionThread` not blocking for the thread to start when invoked concurrently and another thread initiated the start.  This is a very small window with no likely noticeable impact, but was still a simple fix.

name: 6.1 Release
body:
Features and improvements in this release:
* To improve safety and make debugging easier, flatMap will set a `NullPointerException` state if the mapper returns a `null` future
* In `Profiler` the output can be configured to omit stacks which were seen less than X times
* `ListenableFuture` now has the ability to check for an error state without needing an `ExecutionException`: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/e55ad5bb978038c1170488801124be250016abda#diff-43daa81fc2a0173f30f7eee9cd8ea2daR65
* The ability to check error conditions directly enabled a number of performance gains, including reduced GC and computation overheads when mapping futures.

name: 6.0 Release (100th release)
body:
6.0 API update release:
* `org.threadly.test.concurrent` package has been moved to a new artifact at the maven coordinates `org.threadly:threadly-test:1.0`.

* `BlockingQueueConsumer` was replaced with a potentially more performant `Poller.consumeQueue` or a more direct replacement `org.threadly.concurrent.processing.BlockingQueueConsumer`

* `CentralThreadlyPool.lowPriorityPool(boolean)`  was replaced with either `CentralThreadlyPool.lowPrioritySingleThreadPool()` or `CentralThreadlyPool.lowPriorityPool()` 

* `DoNothingRunnable` can not be constructed, instead `DoNothingRunnable.instance()` should be used.

* `RunnableCallableAdapter` can not be constructed, instead the static function `RunnableCallableAdapter.adapt` should be used.

* `RunnableChain` was moved to the package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper`

* `AbstractFutureCallbackFailureHandler` was removed, instead use `ListenableFuture.failureCallback(Consumer)`

* `AbstractFutureCallbackResultHandler` was removed, instead use `ListenableFuture.resultCallback(Consumer)`

* `FutureCallbackExceptionHandlerAdapter` was removed, instead use `ListenableFuture.failureCallback(Consumer)` (which allows an `ExceptionHandler` to be passed in)

* `FutureCallbackFailureHandler` was removed, instead use `ListenableFuture.failureCallback(Consumer)`

* `FutureCallbackResultHandler` was removed, instead use `ListenableFuture.resultCallback(Consumer)`

* `FutureUtils.scheduleWhileTaskResultNull` was removed, instead just implement a small Predicate with a `null` check and use `FutureUtils.scheduleWhile`

* `Watchdog` was renamed and moved to `org.threadly.concurrent.future.watchdog.ConstantTimeWatchdog`

* `WatchdogCache` was renamed and moved to `org.threadly.concurrent.future.watchdog.MixedTimeWatchdog`

* `RunnableFutureCallbackAdapter` was removed without replacement (more precise and performant lambda options are used now)

* `ListenableScheduledFuture` interface was removed without replacement

* `ScheduledFutureDelegate` was removed without replacement

* `StripedLock` was removed without replacement

* A variety of deprecated constructors were replaced, see 5.43 javadocs for details on how to migrate to a still supported constructor

We decided to keep this release smaller by limiting the scope to currently exclude:

* A JVM upgrade will NOT be included, still allowing java 8 and newer.

* Deeper API considerations previously planned for 6.0 are going to be pushed to potentially a 7.0 release.

name: 5.43 Release
body:
This is the last release before the 6.0 major version bump.  This release includes:
* Added `CompletableFutureAdapter` to allow the easy use threadly `ListenableFuture` with `java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture` types.
* `ConstantTimeWatchdog` was improved to reduce `Clock` updates when there is no futures ready to expire (goes from two clock updates to one)
* `KeyDistributedScheduler` has minor GC overhead improvements for recurring tasks
* All classes in `org.threadly.test.concurrent` package are marked as deprecated, now provided from the `org.threadly:threadly-test:0.1` artifact: https://github.com/threadly/threadly-test

name: 5.42 Performance improvements
body:
Includes no new features or API changes.  This release provides:
* Non-locking implementation of `RateLimitingExecutor`, provides significantly improved execution throughput when there is thread contention.
* Minor performance gains for `ExecutorLimiter` by reducing active task permit churn as tasks complete.  This should consequently improve the performance of the `CentralThreadlyPool`.

name: 5.41 Release
body:
5.41 improvements:
* PriorityScheduler by default will resist starting threads for `Starvable` priority tasks.  This default is utilized in `CentralThreadlyPool` to reduce thread sprawl and churn in certain use cases.

* `PriorityScheduler` reduced `Clock` updates for Low and Starvable priority tasks.  This results in these tasks potentially being delayed longer (if the clock is not updating), but can provide notable performance improvements in certain use cases (particularly when the tasks are not ready to execute).

* `PriorityScheduler` optimizations from micro-benchmarks.  Notable performance improvements when comparing against a low priority task for execution, combined with a couple other more minor improvements.

* JVM bug fix with LockSupport use: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/d792e4fd1b4052691869fb2e073cc8628381ce07

* gradle wrapper updated

name: 5.40 Release: Watchdog + RunnableChain API Changes
body:
# API changes
`Watchdog` changes.  Moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.future.watchdog`, there is now three implementations
* `ConstantTimeWatchdog` - this implementation matches the current `Watchdog` exactly, having a timeout specified at construction which all watched futures will be canceled at if they exceed.
* `MixedTimeWatchdog` - This implementation matches the current `WatchdogCache`, allowing the timeout to be specified at time of submission of the future to be watched
* `PollingWatchdog` - This new implementation allows more custom timeout checks, allowing an arbitrary boolean to indicate if a future should be timed out or not.

`RunnableChain` was moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper` due to its nature of just wrapping a collection of Runnable's

name: 5.39 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Minor performance improvements to ListenableFuture transformations
* Stack size improvements for mapped futures
* Added `ConfigureableThreadFactory.builder()` as a way to more easily create these thread factories.
* Gradle build wrapper updated

name: 5.38 Release
body:
Improvements included in this release:
* Added `ArrayIterator` as a way to efficiently go from an `Object` array to an `Iterator<T>`
* `FutureUtils` added some convenience functions where we accept the futures as a vargs
* Added `FutureUtils.makeFirstResultFuture`, this is similar to `invokeAny` in that it will convert a Collection of futures into a single future which will resolve from the first result.  Described in more detail in the commit message: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/4138733b648b7cb715d0916e3ad7f67238c1753d

name: 5.37 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Added `Poller.consumeQueue` as a means to have a `Consumer` invoked as items become available within a queue.  Similar in concept to `BlockingQueueConsumer`, but able to be done on any queue type (not just blocking), and wont start threads (just runs on the `Poller` pool).
* `Poller` can now be constructed with a `SubmitterScheduler` pool rather than a `SchedulerService`
* Added `ListenerOptimizationStrategy.InvokingThreadIfDone` as another optimization option for future listeners
* Added `FlowControlledProcessor` as a way to flow control async processing to avoid memory and other usage that may be caused by submitting too many tasks otherwise
* `BlockingQueueConsumer` was moved to the `org.threadly.concurrent.processing` package, and interfaces updated for modern threadly usage

name: 5.36 Release (ExceptionUtils cause cycle loop fix)
body:
`ExceptionUtils` fixes for when cause traversal can result in an infinite loop.  This has been a deficiency since the start.

There was previously some checking for cycles to the head exception.  This release provides complete protection against all possible cycles.  There is some very minor performances impacts from this (primarily if a cycle exists), however they don't compare to the previous risks of a possible infinite loop.

Functions with cycle cause fixes:
    * `ExceptionUtils.getRootCause`
    * `ExceptionUtils.getCauseOfTypes`
    * `ExceptionUtils.hasCauseOfTypes`
    * `ExceptionUtils.getCauseOfType`
    * `ExceptionUtils.hasCauseOfType`

name: 5.35 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Added `FilteredStackProfiler` as a way to filter out which threads / stacks should be included in the profile
* Deprecated `ListenableFutureTask(boolean, Runnable, Executor)`.  This should mostly be used within the library, so should be low impact.  We wanted to deprecate this to avoid possible confusion with `ListenableFutureTask(boolean, Runnable, Object)` (for the provided result)
* Minor optimizations for error handling with ListenableFuture's

name: 5.34 Release: ListenableFuture API changes and other Future improvements
body:
Changes included in this release:
* `ListenableFuture` API changes from PR #248
  - `ListenableFuture.addCallback`/`addListener` replaced with `callback` and `listener` which now return `this` for a more functional style
  -  Added `ListenableFuture.resultCallback(Consumer<T>)` and `ListenableFuture.failureCallback(Consumer<Throwable>)` as replacements to the classes `AbstractFutureCallback(Result|Failure)Handler` and `FutureCallback(Result|Failure)Handler`. This should be a bit more concise and allows for potential optimizations when only one type is needed. In addition we can also deprecate `FutureCallbackExceptionHandlerAdapter` since `ExceptionHandler` already extends `Consumer<Throwable>`, allowing them to be provided directly into `failureCallback`.
  
* Added statics to `ImmediateResultListenableFuture`:
  - `EMPTY_STRING_RESULT` provides the `String` `""`
  - `EMPTY_OPTIONAL_RESULT` provides `Optional.empty()`
  - `EMPTY_LIST_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptyList()`
  - `EMPTY_MAP_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptyMap()`
  - `EMPTY_SORTED_MAP_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptySortedMap()`
  - `EMPTY_SET_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptySet()`
  - `EMPTY_SORTED_SET_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptySortedSet()`
  - `EMPTY_ITERATOR_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptyIterator()`
  - `EMPTY_LIST_ITERATOR_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptyListIterator()`
  - `EMPTY_ENUMERATION_RESULT` provides `Collections.emptyEnumeration()`

* `FutureUtils.immediateResultFuture` will now provide the above static's for the cases of `Optional.empty()`, `Boolean.TRUE/FALSE`, and the empty `String`.  Other cases are still not optimized due to impact seen in benchmarks.

* Improvements to `FutureUtils` when an empty Collection is provided.  The resulting future now being the `EMPTY_LIST_RESULT` result described above.

name: 5.33 Patch release
body:
Includes several bug fixes and minor improvements:
* `PriorityScheduler` safe point fix for tight loop in `workerIdle` (see Issue #247)
* `PriorityScheduler` tight loop if idle worker thread is interrupted multiple times (would require significant effort to cause)
* `ExceptionUtils.getRootCause` and `ExceptionUtils.hasCauseOfType(s)` improvements to prevent infinite loop if circular cause chain exists

name: 5.32: mapped CancellationException message fix
body: In 5.31 we added the ability to provide debugging information in the `CancellationException` of a `SettableListenableFuture`.  However this information could be easily lost through map / flatMap / failureMap / etc operations.  This fixes that, trying to make this logic a bit more to the core of how ListenableFuture operates.

name: 5.31 Minor Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Added `FutureUtils.invokeAfterAllComplete` as a more efficient alternative to `FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture` and then adding listeners to that future.
* Added `Clock.forwardProgressingDuration` as a minor helper function for finding the duration using the `lastKnownForwardProgressing` time reference
* Minor internal changes to help with improved debugging capabilities in other threadly projects (not public API changes)

name: 5.30 Minor release
body:
Minor release with a couple bug fixes and improvements:
* Fixed bug in `Clock` where `lastKnownForwardProgressingTime` may go backwards between two calls https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/95953e36f6183316e47cce4545629dcfd2c47030

* `FutureUtils.`(`makeResultListFuture`/`makeCompleteListFuture`) order improvements so that the returned futures / results are provided in the order of the original iteration.  This also improves performance here a little after extensive benchmarking.

name: 5.29 Bug fix release
body:
Improvements / bug fixes included in this release:
* `SettableListenableFuture` remove internal `finishCompletion` function to get reduced stack when doing a `map` / `flatMap` function on a `ListenableFuture`
* `StringUtils.all/anyCharsMatch` accept `CharSequence` instead of `String` to be more flexible for cases where converting to a `String` is not desirable
* `FutureUtils.executeWhile` will track the running thread while the predicate is tested, allowing for more accurate `getRunningStack()` results / debugging
* `FutureUtils.executeWhile` will return the running stack of the async future returned from the callable if it's running
* `FutureUtils.executeWhile` and `FutureUtils.scheduleWhile` now correctly will propagate cancellations on the returned future to the delegate future which is processing the result.  This is more consistent with other mapping functionality.

name: 5.28 Release
body:
Bug fixes included in release:
* `ListenableFuture.flatMap` `cancel` fix.  Fixes a case where canceling a `flatMap`'ed future would not cancel the future it was depending on execution for.  Described in more detail on this commit: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/d2a0cb1bea11a002aedfd60c7f1fd6b2043ba60f

New features and improvements included in this release:
* Added `ListenableFuture.getRunningStackTrace()` to get the stack trace of the future being executed, or a parent future (if being invoked on a mapped future that is still waiting on the parent futures result).
* Added `CancelDebuggingListenableFuture` as a future wrapper to make use of the above in order to get the running stack at the point at which a future was canceled.
* `ImmediateResultListenableFuture` performance improvements when `failureMap`'ing.  An improvement to a previous improvement that in some cases was not being fully realized.

name: 5.27 Internal improvement release
body: Further improvements in `RateLimiterExecutor` as a continuation from 5.26.

name: 5.26 Internal improvement release
body:
Deprecations:
* `RunnableCallableAdapter` constructor was deprecated, instead static function `RunnableCallableAdapter.adapt` should be used.

Improvements included in this release:
* Internal changes to `RunnableCallableAdapter` now allow for better heap usage when `DoNothingRunnable` is being used in the cases of Futures with or without results.
* Internal minor performance improvements to `PriorityScheduler` and `NoThreadScheduler` / `SingleThreadScheduler`

name: 5.25 Release
body:
This release includes a variety of improvements to the utility `Profiler`:
* Thread names are checked at polling time, so if threads are renamed we will try to indicate the different names we witnessed
* Profiled threads are now sorted by their name, hopefully grouping similar threads together
* Common stack traces (like idle `PriorityScheduler` threads for example) are now simplified in `Profiler` output
* Minor performance improvements and memory usage reductions

Other improvements:
* `TestCondition` was improved to allow a `Supplier<T>` / `Predicate<T>` constructor, so that on failure the last result / condition can be reported
* `ListenableFuture.mapFailure` generics improvements.  Not likely to be realized except for in very specific situations.

Other changes / deprecations:
* `StripedLock` is deprecated for removal (if you want this maintained in 6.0 please open an issue).  PR #239 and #240 removed our internal use of it by instead using `Map.compute` as a way of doing per-key memory barriers.  Feel free to open an issue if you want to discuss maintaining it.  Current thoughts are that those changes are likely simpler (despite the complexity of capturing results from inside `compute` blocks).  This also resulted in several constructors where an estimated `parallismLevel` could be specified in being deprecated.  As those PR's show other internal (but otherwise should be transparent) changes were done to support this.
* `DoNothingRunnable` should no longer be constructed, but instead referenced by `DoNothingRunnable.instance()`
* `KeyedRateLimiterExecutor` no longer schedules a task per key.  Instead it has a single task to examine all keys.  This may result in limiters living a bit longer, but should overall perform better under heavy load.

name: 5.24 Bug fix release
body: A bug fix release to address locking introduced in 5.24 with `SettableListenableFuture.addFutureCallback`.  This further improves the performance of adding a callback, but also solves the defect introduced where the lock may be held while invoking the callback.

name: 5.23 Release
body:
Bug fixes:
* Profiler now works correctly when it is started using a `SameThreadSubmitterExecutor` which will of course cause the `start` to block until stopped, but at least it can be stopped now.

Improvements included in this release:
* Significant performance improvements with `SettableListenableFuture`, particularly when reporting failures to `FutureCallback`'s
* `ExceptionHandler` interface now extends the `Consumer<Throwable>` interface with a default function provided.  This is just a convenience so that any `Consumer<Throwable>` needs can be provided from these threadly implementations.

Deprecations:
* `ListenableScheduledFuture` and `ScheduledFutureDelegate` have been deprecated and moved closer to the classes that use them under the `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.compatibility` package

name: 5.22 Bug fix release
body: Includes another condition to the fix provided in 5.21 where FutureUtil collection futures are not mapping the cancellation state correctly.

name: 5.21 Bug fix release
body: Another bug fix, this time when communicating mapped futures canceled state.  This time solving issues from `FutureUtils` where collections of futures are collapsed into a single future.

name: 5.20 Release
body:
Improvements in this release:
* Fixed bug where `SettableListenableFutures` may not cancel when `cancel` is extended.  This was relevant for communicating the canceled state in a mapped `ListenableFuture`, so should be considered a significant bug if you use `map` or `flatMap` functions.
* Internal performance improvements when using `FutureCallback`'s
* Added `StackTracker` as a way to choose when to manually "profile" the stack traces (see issue #187).

name: 5.19 Release
body:
Improvements and changes included in 5.19:
* Added `ListenableFuture.flatMap(ListenableFuture)` as a convenience equivalent to `ListenableFuture.flatMap((ignored) -> future)`
* Minor javadoc improvements
* Added `WatchdogCache.centralWatchdogCache` as an improvement when multiple `WatchdogCache`'s are needed without a specified backing pool.
* `RunnableListenerHelper` micro optimizations for when a single listener is specified.  This will improve the GC overhead and speed of ListenableFuture's being mapped (but only slightly).
* `ListenableFuture` transformations were not respecting the `ListenerOptimizationStrategy.SingleThreadIfExecutorMatchOrDone` optimization is now actually done if the future is already done as requested.
* Further reductions in stack depths generated by threadly when doing future mapping operations.

Deprecations:
* `ExceptionUtils.runRunnable` was deprecated.  Internally its use has been removed in an effort to reduce stack depths seen from the threadly project.  This only incurs a minor jar size penalty in duplicating this small function.

name: 5.18 Release
body:
* Improvements when WatchdogCache is used with a wide range of millisecond resolution timeout values.

(was meant to be included in 5.17, but got missed)

name: 5.17 Release
body:
Improvements included in this release:
* Added `ListenableFuture.mapFailure` and `ListenableFuture.flatMapFailure` as ways of converting exceptions / failure statue futures to either results or different potential failures.
* Internal improvements to `ListenableFuture.flatMap` provide both stack reductions and minor performance improvements.

name: 5.16 Release
body:
Bug fixes:
* `CentralThreadlyPool` `isolatedTask` pool for recurring tasks would decrease the central pool size after every run.  This would result in an exception to be logged every time it tried to then decrease the pool size.

New features:
* `FutureUtils.executeWhile` was added.  This is similar to `scheduleWhile` except that execution happens immediately.  No pool is even needed to be passed here, as we can jump our execution off from the previous `ListenableFuture`.

Deprecations:
* `FutureUtils.scheduleWhileTaskResultNull` has been deprecated without replacement.  Transitioning to provide a `Predicate` like `(o) -> o != null` seems like an easy transition.  Having this specific variation would otherwise result in a proliferation of the api and might make things confusing.

Improvements:
* A reduction in the stack sizes produced when using threadly monads.  If mapping a future multiple times it can result in a very large stack size.  This still true, but it's size should be reduced by between 1/4 and 1/3 what it was in 5.15.

name: 5.15 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* Added `ThreadReferencingThreadFactory` as a way to get a handle on the currently alive threads produced by a thread factory.
* `CentralThreadlyPool` now lets you set the thread priority (for the scheduler) for single threaded pools
* `CentrealThreadlyPool` had an API change for its low priority pool, now having separate functions for `singleThread` instead of taking in a boolean.
* `ReschedulingOperation` can now be constructed with just an `Executor` instead of requiring a scheduler
* `SchedulerServiceLimiter` had two defects fixed:
- Recurring tasks could not be removed while they were running
- Recurring tasks would take two slots for every task running

name: 4.10.0 Backport release
body:
This includes some improvements that have been included in 5.X.  Back ported for people still on pre-java 8 needs.
This should include fixes for all known flaws in 4.X.
It includes improvements that could be easily backported and does not rely on newer java functionality.  5.X still contains a LOT more than this, but this at least provides some things.

Back ported bug fixes:
  * `StripedLock` `Integer.MIN_VALUE` overflow issue has been fixed ( 743229c70ba11ded431cc9cd7501af31faeb1e0c )

  * `UnfairExecutor` overflow issue fixed when stripe is `Long.MIN_VALUE` ( f94729121b9303338b262806e42e606afb23db69 )

  * `ListenableFutureTask` nulls out callable after execution to allow garbage collection even if future is held ( 5f8f77592bf10e7a3606566833cfd0dbb108828e )

  * `PriorityScheduler` and `SingleThreadScheduler` fix for not waiting on low priority tasks to complete on shutdown ( cdf7791d7fa1ac82a651c2e8e234298836aae879 )

Back ported features and other improvements:
  * `RunnableListenerHelper` execution improvements back ported, allowing for more efficent ListenableFuture's ( 1d98056c4e3f91eaa19c890044b9ed63472bedd0 f2197a7de2e3beb1ea6d63c9537f6ac921d2864c 5707d08bbfc3590486ae62da5aead1b2252eae37 )

  * `ExecutorLimiter` performance improvement to reduce locking by checking state before hand ( 11684dcdfc895dd2e9c728b644a09529eeb2ad70 )

  * `FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture` optimization when providing a list that is either empty or contains a single item ( a101bb2650506894a4c5722c859c2152cb8b6264 )

  * `ReschedulingOperation` Allow it to be signaled for immediate execution ( 5d56ee862d2dc8971ae812c82f6b853e6e5bc95b )

  * `ExceptionHandler` default implementations for ignoring and printing the stack trace are now available

  * `ImmediateResultListenableFuture` static instances for `Boolean` results are now available ( 9f1324b6aec01971d62e2aec7b99340d6d44119b )

  * Deprecated `ControlledThreadProfiler.removedProfiledThread` to be removed in 6.0 for better named `removeProfiledThread` ( 39c32dc588ca6c4c2850999e420de0d64e64020c )

  * Deprecated `RunnableFutureCallbackAdapter` for 6.0 removal ( 1b2c6b8a79ba40f5e6a654ce3d673003c39f03d1 )

name: 5.14 Release
body:
Minor feature expansion, added `StringUtils.allCharsMatch` and `StringUtils.anyCharsMatch` functionality.

Also fixed some minor javadocs errors.

name: 5.13 Release
body:
Minor improvements for 5.13.  Prior to 5.0 this probably would not have been enough to release but with 5.0 we are trying to have more frequent smaller releases.

Changes and improvements included in this release:
* Renamed `ControlledThreadProfiler.removedProfiledThread` to `removeProfiledThread`
* Performance improvements for `FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture` and `makeFailurePropagatingCompleteFuture` when providing a result Object
* Deprecate `RunnableFutureCallbackAdapter` without replacement.  The thought being this is not likely useful to anyone outside of the library so we want to hide visibility to make javadoc surfing easier.  If this is useful, please open an issue to request the visibility to remain public.
* Internal operation improvements (not really bugs, just more tolerant to specific situations) with `Watchdog`, `FutureUtils`, and `ExecutorLimiter`/other limiters

name: 5.12 Bug fix release
body:
Release to fix recent regression when using ListenableFuture optimizations

A highly unlikely race condition was introduced where a future may complete while the optimization is being checked resulting in an on-thread execution that was not desired.
If `SingleThreadIfExecutorMatch` was passed and the entire optimization check statement has completed before the thread is suspended, and then only resumed once the future has fully completed, the provided listener will invoke on the calling thread even though not desired to do so.
This is fixed by extending this optimization capabilities to the `RunnableListenableHelper` where this decision is atomically made.

name: 5.11 Release
body:
Changes included in this release:
* `FutureUtils.scheduleWhile` when the predicate throws an exception will have it provided to `ExceptionUtils.handleException` so it can be treated like any other uncaught exception.
* The 5.10 changes to treat exceptions thrown from the mapper `Function` in `ListenableFuture.map` showed to make a potentially legit use case harder to do.  So `throwMap` was added to provide the pre-5.10 behavior of `map`.  Specifically `throwMap` expects exceptions to be thrown from the mapper function so that it can translate the future into a failure state. 
* Improvements to GC when executor optimizations are used

name: 5.10 Release
body:
Changes / Fixes / Improvements included in this release:
* `UnfairExecutor` fix when stripe returned is `Long.MIN_VALUE`
* `Runnable`/`ListenerHelper` improvements where a in-thread listener may prevent other listeners from being submitted to their execution pool
* Possible execution optimizations now available using `ListenableFuture.ListenerOptimizationStrategy` (see javadocs for details)

name: 5.9 Patch release
body:
Patch release to fix possible error with Integer.MIN_VALUE hash code result in `StripedLock`

https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/743229c70ba11ded431cc9cd7501af31faeb1e0c

name: 5.8 Release
body:
This release includes minor feature expansions and a small deprecation / rename.

* Deprecated `PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper` for the shorter named `DefaultPriorityWrapper` under the new `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.priority` package.

* Added `PriorityDelegatingScheduler` as a way to having the priority choose which scheduler you are delegating to.

name: 5.7 Release
body:
Improvements / changes in this release:
* Added `CentralThreadlyPool` this pool tries to reduce the need for constructing one off pools for small tasks.  By removing this need you no longer need to worry about the thread pool lifecycle (no shutting down these pools).  And in addition you are providing the central pool the ability to try and reduce thread churn across the application.  Pools returned from this may incur some additional (minor) overhead in task execution, but nothing that should be significant.  For high throughput, and long lived / high usage pools, you may not want to replace them with this, but there is the potential to do so if you prefer.

* `ExecutorLimiter` now has the capabilities of no longer limiting monad / listener functionality.  When you add a listener without an executor (or a `map` function), that listener will invoke on the thread which completed the task execution as well.  This means that the `Limiter` will also restrict during those actions.  This change allows you to allow the limiter to release the limit as soon as the core task completes, not counting listener / monad functions against the limit.  You can gain this new behavior by using the new constructor and specifying `false` for the `limitFutureListenersExecution`

* Added `SingleThreadSchedulerSubPool` as a possibly more efficient alternative to other Limiter's when you want to limit it down to a single thread.  This also is the only limiter that provides `TaskPriority` handling logic.  However it does have some different behavior characteristics compared to other limiters (for example in how it tries to steal delegate pool cpu time as long as necessary to get all tasks completed, rather than needing to be individually queued against the parent scheduler).

* Added `ThreadRenamingPriorityScheduler`.  This is similar to other `ThreadRenaming` schedulers/executors, but implements the `PrioritySchedulerService` interface.

name: 5.6 Release
body:
Improvements included in this release:

* Added Pair.iterateLeft/Right as a way to convert iterators of Pair's into just one half (without the need to do a copy like collectLeft/Right requires).
* Added `ImmediateResultListenableFuture.BOOLEAN_TRUE_RESULT` and `FALSE` equivalent for having a common static already complete future with a boolean contained.
* Improved cancelations for `ListenableFuture`'s returned by `.map` and `.flatMap`.  Previously you could only cancel if the original source future has not started at all.  This allows you to cancel and interrupt at any point in the mapped chain of events.  If an interrupt is not requested then the old behavior is preserved, only allowing the future to be canceled if the starting / sourced future has not started.

name: 5.5 Patch: Shutdown low priority task completion
body:
This fixes an issue in PriorityScheduler and SingleThreadScheduler where invoking .shutdown() will not wait for low priority tasks to complete before the pool shuts down (only waiting for High priority tasks).
Starvable tasks are considered starvable and thus there is not consideration in waiting for them to complete before shutdown occurs.

name: Threadly Version: 5.4
body:
Improvements / Changes included in this release:
* Default implements of `ExceptionHandler.PRINT_STACKTRACE_HANDLER` and `ExceptionHandler.IGNORE_HANDLER` now available.
* Added `StringUtils.nonEmptyOptional` as a way to get a `Optional` dependent on if a valid, non-empty string is provided or not.
* `ExecutorLimiter` and `KeyedExecutorLimiter` now allow the limit to be adjusted after construction
* `ReschedulingOperation` now has a new function to indicate it should be rescheduled for "immediate" execution.
* General performance improvements found from new benchmarks on new AMD thread ripper setup.  Our benchmarks are currently being updated and improved.

name: Threadly Version: 5.3
body:
Improvements in 5.3 release:
* `ListenableFutureTask`: Null out callable after task completes.  This can provide a substantial garbage collection benefit if holding on to the futures.
* `FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture`: optimization when provided List with either empty or one future.
* Javadoc corrections `@since` tag corrections

name: Threadly Version: 5.2
body:
Improvements and changes included in this release:
* `ExecutorLimiter` (and all limiters which depend on it) have performance improvements due to reduced locking.
* `SchedulerService.getWaitingForExecutionTaskCount()` added.  Similar to `getQueuedTaskCount()`, except it goes through a little extra computational overhead to only report tasks which are ready for execution.
* `RunnableListenerHelper` Has performance improvements when it will only execute listeners once.  This is particularly relevant because it improves all `ListenableFuture` performance as well.

name: Patch version: 5.1
body:
5.1 PriorityScheduler fix for threads not unparking

An optimization introduced in 5.0 can interact with user applications that use `LockSupport` to park/unpark.  This can happen just simple things like blocking on a future, or using a ReentrantLock.
The solution is just to reset the state once we know the thread is within our control before we park.  The best place for this seems to before we queue the thread as parked.

Lots of benchmarking occured in this change since this does reduce the original benefit.  In fact the advantage to no optimization at all is minor at best.  I suspect this might be a place for further optimization in the future.  Right now it does make sense to reduce the unparks due to the seperate peek / remove time (don't want threads wasting time inspecting tasks they can't execute).  A global check shows benefit in some use cases but worst in others.  In contrast an aggressive unpark (like searching for a parked thread) also shows benefit in some cases more than others.  This current solution is currently designed to be a safe compromise.

name: Threadly Version: 5.0
body:
5.0 includes a wide variety of improvements, new features, as well as cleanup / deprecations of old ones.  The most notable single change is the drop in support for java 6 and 7.  However with that we have been able to make internal and ergonomic improvements for java 8 and newer users.

## Deprecations that were removed:
* `AbstractDelayed` removed without replacement

* `PrioritySchedulerLimiter` removed without replacement

* Interface deprecations/removals
  - `SubmitterExecutorInterface` -> `SubmitterExecutor`
  - `SimpleSchedulerInterface` -> `SchedulerService`
  - `SchedulerServiceInterface` -> `SchedulerService`
  - `PrioritySchedulerInterface` -> `PrioritySchedulerService`
  - `RunnableContainerInterface` -> `RunnableContainer`

* `org.threadly.concurrent.PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker` was replaced with `org.threadly.concurrent.statistics.PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker`

* `StringUtils.NEW_LINE` was removed since in JDK 1.7 and newer `System.lineSeparator()` can be a direct replacement.

* Wrappers moved into wrapper package (with additional sub packages to keep things easier to find)

* ExecutorWrapper renamed into SubmitterExecutorAdapter (longer but more descriptive).

* PrioritySchedulerWrapper was replaced with PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper

* Thread renaming wrapper classes deprecated and renamed to be brief (without loosing clarity):
  - `ThreadRenamingExecutorWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingExecutor`
  - `ThreadRenamingRunnableWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingRunnable`
  - `ThreadRenamingSchedulerServiceWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingSchedulerService`
  - `ThreadRenamingSubmitterSchedulerWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingSubmitterScheduler`

*  `ChainedRunnableListenableFuture` and `ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture` were removed without replacement.  These classes were hard to use correctly, and only useful in very limited situations (and with improved pool benchmarks those situations are even fewer than before).  If anyone has a use for these classes open a github issue.  I feel like there could be some alternative implementations which are simpler and better (but only want to provide such a thing if there is a need).

* Many function name changes:
 * `StringUtils.randomString` (now use `makeRandomString`)
 * `StringUtils.makeNonNull` (now use `nullToEmpty`)

* Thread `Profiler` can no longer be constructed with output dump file

## Improvements added to 5.0:
* Significant Javadoc formatting improvements

* Performance improvements from being able to leverage java 8 added functionality

* Added Monads to `ListenableFuture`.  See `ListenableFuture.map` and `ListenableFuture.flatMap`.  

* In addition `FutureUtils.scheduleWhile` provides a nice way to have an async looping operation.

* Added `Poller` as a way to poll for state (through Supplier, or `java.util.concurrent.Future` result), with a `ListenableFuture` returned as a way to be notified when the state changes.

* Ergonomics improvements with the use of java 8 (included but not limited to task interceptors, `TestCondition`, `Pair`).

* `Pair` now also has additional features for transforming collections of pairs.

* `ListenerHelper` and `InvokationTee` updated to handle `default` interface functions which return a result.

## Internal improvements in 5.0:
* Performance and memory usage improvements to stripedLock (typically just used internally)

* An exception is handled when `AbstractService` is garbage collected without being stopped

* `ReschedulingOperation` has a fix for a potential state while going through individual if condition checks.

* `PriorityScheduler` has performance improvements where unnecessary `unpark` calls are reduced.

name: Threadly Version: 4.9.0
body:
4.9.0 will be the last feature expansion release before the 5.0.0 release.

Improvements/changes included in this release:
- Added `FutureUtils.makeFailurePropagatingCompleteFuture` which is similar to `FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture` except it will propagate cancellation or failures from the provided futures to the returned one.
- Added `ListenableFutureAdapterTask` as a way to adapt a `java.util.concurrent.Future` into a threadly `ListenableFuture`.  Right now this would require you to block a thread to make this conversion, but threadly 5.0.0 will provide a way to use this where the state will be polled, rather than blocking a thread.
- `PrioritySchedulerServiceQueueLimitRejector` now has the ability to have starvable tasks be ignored from the queue limit
- Minor profiler performance improvements.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.8.1
body:
This is a critical patch release.  A bug, introduced in `4.4.0`, in code common to `PriorityScheduler` and `SingleThreadScheduler` around recurring tasks can result in the task queue becoming incorrectly sorted.  Once the queue becomes unsorted it is potentially possible that some recurring tasks may never execute again (normal execution and one time scheduled tasks should continue to operate normally).

It is only possible for this bug to be hit if fixed rate recurring tasks are used (in comparison to fixed delay), or if task scheduling actions are happening in parallel to tasks rescheduling themselves.  While unlikely to be hit by most production systems, this is one of the most severe bugs in Threadly's history and it is HIGHLY encouraged you update your applications immediately.

name: Threadly Version: 4.8.0
body:
## Improvements and new features:
- Added `PrioritySchedulerServiceQueueLimitRejector`.  Similar to other queue limiting wrappers, this one is just for the `PrioritySchedulerService`
- Limiter wrappers: Instead of only throwing `RejectedExecutionException`'s we now can accept a `RejectedExecutionHandler` in order to perform other actions.  By default we still throw `RejectedExecutionException`.
- Moved `getQueuedTaskCount(TaskPriority)` definition from AbstractPriorityScheduler and into the `PrioritySchedulerService` interface.  Thus allowing you to still have access to this priority specific functionality while passing around the interface.
- Added `SuppressedStackRuntimeException`.  This exception type can be extended to prevent stack generation (which can be expensive in java).
- Added `ExceptionUtils.makeRuntime(Throwable, boolean)` which allows you to use the above new wrapper exception type to avoid stack generation.
- Added `Pair.split` which is equivalent (but more efficient) than invoking `Pair.collectLeft` and `Pair.collectRight`.  `Pair.split` takes a collection of Pair's and returns a single pair that contains two collections (one for the left side, one for the right side).
- Added ability for `RateLimiterExecutor` and `KeyedRateLimiterExecutor` to at construction time accept a maximum delay, and start to reject tasks if they are too backed up.  This seems like a common need, and while it can be done externally to this class, it's annoying and less efficient.
- RateLimiterExecutor: In execute that accepts permits we now return the milliseconds the task was delayed.  We can't always do this because in all other cases we are implementing an interface or already returning a future.  But this one condition is at least a little more flexible now.

## Deprecations:
- Deprecated for 5.0.0 removal `StringUtils.NEW_LINE`.  In JDK 1.7 and newer `System.lineSeparator()` can be a perfect replacement.
- ExecutorWrapper renamed into SubmitterExecutorAdapter (longer but more descriptive).
- Thread renaming wrapper classes deprecated and renamed to be brief (without loosing clarity):
  -   `ThreadRenamingExecutorWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingExecutor`
  -   `ThreadRenamingRunnableWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingRunnable`
  -   `ThreadRenamingSchedulerServiceWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingSchedulerService`
  -   `ThreadRenamingSubmitterSchedulerWrapper` -> `ThreadRenamingSubmitterScheduler`
-  `ChainedRunnableListenableFuture` and `ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture` were deprecated without replacement.  These classes were hard to use correctly, and only useful in very limited situations (and with improved pool benchmarks those situations are even fewer than before).  If anyone has a use for these classes open a github issue.  I feel like there could be some alternative implementations which are simpler and better (but only want to provide such a thing if there is a need).
- `SubmitterSchedulerQueueLimitRejector` deprecated `getCurrentQueueSize()` for `getQueuedTaskCount()`.  This is a more consistent name with the rest of the library.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.7.2
body:
Small patch release to include three small improvements in FutureUtils:
- Added FutureUtils.cancelIncompleteFuturesIfAnyFail.  This takes in a collection of futures, and will add a listener to each one so that if any fail in failure then will all be canceled.  This is a common pattern to avoid doing unnecessary work when you need the results from multiple individual tasks.
- Performance improvements with `makeFailureListFuture` and `makeResultListFuture` when provided lots of canceled futures.  If using `FutureUtils.cancelIncompleteFutures` on a large collection of futures, and then using `makeFailureListFuture` or `makeResultListFuture` would result in a lot of unnecessarily load as we optimistically try to pull the results from the canceled futures.  Instead we check for this condition to avoid having an exception constructed and thrown as a way of communicating the state.
- Behavior improvement when future canceled from FutureUtils.makeResultListFuture.  Previously if a future was canceled this would be treated just like any other error, potentially resulting in the returned future throwing an ExecutionException.  Worse yet this canceled future may have hidden a more interesting error from one of the futures.  Now if one or more futures are canceled, but NO futures end in error, then the returned future will also be canceled.  If one or more futures is canceled, but at least one future IS in error, then we will ignore the canceled conditions and fail the returned future with the more interesting failure.  This is a huge benefit in traceability for issues.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.7.1
body: Just added `getTrackedKeyCount()` to key based limiters.  This was found to be important for the newly introduced `KeyedRateLimiterExecutor` since it schedules tasks itself for maintaining the managed keys.

name: Threadly Version: 4.7.0
body:
Two minor new features: 
- Added 'KeyedRateLimiterExecutor' - Similar to `KeyedExecutorLimiter` in that it applies the limit on a per key base, but with the behavior of a `RateLimiterExecutor`
- Added `SchedulerExecutorDelegator` - Providing the ability to delegate scheduling and executing to two different implementations.  A potential example of how this could be useful is when in combination with a `PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper` you could assign different default priorities depending on if a task is scheduled or immediately executed.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.6.3
body:
Includes some minor improvements since the 4.6.2 release.  No actual bugs were fixed, but the changes were not enough to justify a 4.7.0 release (but still wanted to release them consistently).

Improvements included in this release:
- FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture memory usage improvements (previously allocated an object per future, now the same object can be reused on all provided futures)
- RateLimiterExecutor: Allow rate to be adjusted dynamically
- Improved javadocs @since annotations to be more accurate since the wrapper package move
- Internal code clarity changes (nothing functional)

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.6.2
body:
Patch release to fix a defect found in `PriorityScheduler` where an idle thread my fail to shutdown when the pool is shutdown or when the pool size is decreased.

This was a very tight race condition that was introduced in 4.4.0.

Please see pull request #204 for more details about the solution/issue.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.6.1
body:
API breaking patch release to fix `interceptor` being spelled as `intercepter`.

This is a special case in that it is a quick spelling correction in the new 'interceptor' functionality that was introduced in 4.6.0. While we normally would never release an API breaking change till a major version, this is viewed more as a bug fix since it was introduced literally less than 24 hours ago.

name: Threadly Version: 4.6.0
body:
This release primarily includes internal structure changes, and package moves.  It does deprecate a lot of things due to these package moves.  However hopefully it will make the javadocs easier to explore.  Since threadly is heavily built on this idea of "wrapping" pools, it makes sense to have a "wrapper" package which you can find these wrappers from.

Improvements included in this release:
- Added ability to intercept tasks before they are added to the pool by using wrappers in `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.intercepter`
- Added ExceptionUtils hasCauseOfType and getCauseOfType, which provides easy ways to determine if an exception chain at some point had a specific exception type included.  This can be used for creating more robust error handling, or for shortening exception stacks.
- Minor performance improvements for NoThreadScheduler (which in turn will improve SingleThreadScheduler)
- Minor performance improvements with Clock updater thread.  We now avoid updating the clock if it was naturally updated anyways.  This should reduce the kernel overhead even further (but not by a ton since it only happened 10 times a second anyways).  One thing that makes threadly unique is our very few system clock call invocations, and this only furthers that design idea.
- Internal code duplication reductions between NoThreadScheduler and PriorityScheduler

Deprecations / class moves in this release:
- Deprecated `ListUtils`, this will have a replacement in 5.0.0 called `SortUtils`.  This new implementation will have much cleaner interfaces.
- Deprecated `ListenerHelper.build()`, `AsyncListenerHelper.build()` and `DefaultExecutorListenerHelper.build()`.  Since these functions only existed as reduced sugar, and since java 8 makes that reduced sugar no longer as important, we will go ahead and no longer support these in threadly 5.X
- Moved package `org.threadly.concurrent.limiter` to `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.limiter`
- Moved `PrioritySchedulerServiceWrapper`, `ScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper`, `SingleThreadSchedulerServiceWrapper` to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.compatibility`
- Moved `ExecutorStatisticWrapper` to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.statistics`
- `ThreadRenamingExecutorWrapper`, `ThreadRenamingRunnableWrapper`, `ThreadRenamingSchedulerServiceWrapper`, `ThreadRenamingSubmitterSchedulerWrapper` into package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper.traceability`
- `ExecutorWrapper` was moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper`
- `KeyDistributedExecutor` and `KeyDistributedScheduler` was moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper`
- `PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper` was moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper`
- `ThrowableSuppressingRunnable` was moved to package `org.threadly.concurrent.wrapper`

name: Threadly Version: 4.5.0
body:
Changes/Improvements/Additions included in this release:

New features and improvements:
- Added "UnfairExecutor".  An executor (no scheduling) that is designed to provide less guarantees, but as much performance as possible.  If planning to use it please read the javadocs carefully.
- Improved "Pair" `collectLeft` and `collectRight` API to be more forgiving with incoming generics (no functional changes needed)
- Added "StatisticsUtils" for both internal and external help around getting basic statistics
- Added "ExecutorStatisticWrapper", while the PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker is still a better option for statistics from the PriorityScheduler.  This is the start of being able to wrap schedulers to get basic statistics from any arbitrary executor.
- Added "NoThreadSchedulerStatisticTracker" and "SingleThreadSchedulerStatisticTracker" to complete options of possible statistic trackers.  These follow the more common api specified in the above statistic trackers.

Bug fixes:
- Fixed issue in ExecutorQueueLimitRejector and SubmitterSchedulerQueueLimitRejector where if the parent (wrapped) scheduler/executor throws a RejectedExecutionException the queue count would be forever too large.
- Sort of a bug fix, I consider the behavior unexpected (or at a minimum undesired).  When removing a Future task from PriorityScheduler, NoThreadScheduler, or SingleThreadScheduler it would cancel the future (without an interrupt).  This is the same if removing from `.remove(Task)` or `.shutdownNow()`.  This behavior has been changed, so that futures will be left untouched.  Allowing the user to manually cancel them (possibly with FutureUtils), or possibly re-execute them on another scheduler.

Deprecations (to be removed in 5.0.0):
- Deprecated "PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker" at old location, and created a new one located at org.threadly.concurrent.statistics.PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker
- Deprecated in the "SchedulerService" interface `getCurrentRunningCount` for the shorter and better named `getActiveTaskCount`.  This is more consistent, closer to what is in java.util (so hopefully easier to find in the docs), and shorter in name.
- Deprecated in the "SchedulerService" interface `getScheduledTaskCount` for the shorter and better named `getQueuedTaskCount`.  This is more consistent and a bit shorter in name.
- Deprecated in "SingleThreadScheduler" `shutdownAndAwaitTermination`, `shutdownAndAwaitTermination`, `shutdownNowAndAwaitTermination`  .Instead replacing them with the more common `awaitTermination()` and `awaitTermination(long)`.
- Deprecated KeyDistributedExecutor's `getSubmitterForKey` to be renamed into `getExecutorForKey`
- Similar to above KeyDistributedScheduler's `getSubmitterSchedulerForKey` has been renamed to `getSchedulerForKey`

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.4.3
body:
This is again a small patch release, this time focused around the behavior of canceling futures.  This is most notable in our ScheduledExecutorService Wrapper's.  Historically in threadly when you cancel a future it ends up being a no-op task once executed (but not removed from execution).  Because ScheduledExecutorService returns futures for recurring tasks (which otherwise threadly does not support), if you cancel that future it just ends up being a no-op each time it executes.  This patch release changes that behavior so that those ScheduledExecutorService wrappers will remove the task when a recurring task's future is canceled.

The threadly implementations still do the more performant option of just letting the task become a no-op when canceled, and if removal is desired you must explicitly remove the task.  However we did change the shutdownNow behavior of SingleThreadScheduler and PriorityScheduler so that it wont return canceled tasks in its list of tasks waiting for execution.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.4.2
body:
This includes a fix for the PrioritySchedulerStatistic tracker where recurring tasks would skew the results to get the delays.  This was filed as issue #188

This also includes a VERY minor feature enhancement.  Even though this is a patch release it did not seem worth waiting for 4.3.0 to release.  PriorityScheduler now has a native awaitTermination() functionality.  Thus avoiding the need to make a polling design if this behavior is desired. #191

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.4.1
body:
This is a bug fix release to fix a very hard to hit, and tight condition as described in issue #189.  The condition causes scheduled tasks to possibly be delayed in execution, despite the pool having free threads.  Issue #189 describes the conditions necessary to hit this issue in detail.

This also includes a fix where a PriorityScheduler constructed with > 1 threads, with a SINGLE recurring task would have a thread spin 100% while that recurring task was running.

This also fixes a condition that was known at the time of the 4.4.0 release where a scheduler with > 1 threads, but only a single recurring task will result in a thread spinning 100% WHILE that recurring task is being executed.

For more details in these please read the commit message here: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/bd6a67273ea70ad92facb1b8f27e939b3e3fd548

As well as issue #189

name: Threadly Version: 4.4.0
body:
Improvements:
- Massive internal improvements to the PriorityScheduler!  It now operates with one less thread, the thread used for managing queues is now removed, and instead that work is done by all the pools threads as they become idle.  This was a difficult change, because one motivation was to reduce the locking that must occur, and reduce the thread boundaries a task must pass through.  This meant that code that previously was only operated on in a single threaded way, must become thread safe (without locking).  It was months in the making, but ultimately we got a reliable solution.  The best part, it's way faster.  We don't have ongoing benchmarks posted yet (also in the works), but the change is really quite impressive.  Depending on your use case, you can see anywhere from 45% on up performance improvement in task execution rate.  In every case blowing the java.util scheduler out of the water.
- Improved/fixed issue where RunnableListenerHelper would invoke added listeners while holding a lock if the helper has already completed.  This improves the handling of listeners for all ListenableFuture's.
- Added AbstractFutureCallbackFailureHandler, AbstractFutureCallbackResultHandler, FutureCallbackExceptionHandlerAdapter.  These implementations are just to reduce boiler plate code.  Allowing you to create FutureCallback implementations which care for just the result, or just the failure condition.
- Added tuple classes "Pair" and "MutablePair".  I find myself wanting these from time to time, the latest being in ambush.  So I added them as a little utility class.
- Switched RunnableListenerHelper and ListenerHelper to use a list of "Pair's" described above instead of a HashMap.  This has a sizable improvement of both listener add time, and the amount of heap used.  Though it does mean if a listener is added multiple times it will be invoked multiple times (where previously just the last addition was used).  Please see the discussion on #177 for more information, and the change can be seen in PR #179.
- Added Clock.accurateNanoTime() and Clock.lastKnownNanoTime().  Allowing access to the stored nano time without the conversion to milliseconds.
- Improved ExecutorService wrappers for invokeAll when no timeout is provided, we now avoid clock calls during that case.

Fixes:
- Fixed issue where sending a thread interrupt to a unit test thread can cause TestCondition to spin loop (without parking).
- Improved ability to run unit tests reliably on slow systems

Deprecations:
- Deprecated Clock.systemNanoTime, instead use Clock.accurateNanoTime
- Deprecated AbstractDelayed.  Since this abstract implementation has no meaningful value inside threadly, and because it likely only would have value to other pool developers it does not seem worth the jar size.  If anyone is actually using this let me know via a github issue and lets discuss.
- Deprecated (Abstract)PriorityScheduler.makeWithDefaultPriority.  We are trying to stop sprinkling these helper/wrapper functions everywhere.  Instead to keep things more concise and uniform you should manually wrap the scheduler in a PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper

name: Threadly Version: 4.3.0
body:
Lots of changes and improvements included in this release....4.3.0

Improvements and additions:
- Added "InvocationTee" which allows you to easily multiple calls to multiple instances of a given interface.  This has several ways which invocations can be distributed to the provided instances.
- NoThreadScheduler, SingleThreadScheduler, and TestableScheduler now implement the PrioritySchedulerInterface (and thus have an extension of functionality to include and handle different priorities for tasks)
- Added new "TaskPriority" "Starvable"...this priority is below "Low" and in fact will only run when the scheduler has absolutely nothing else it can run.  Thus these tasks can be starved if the scheduler never becomes idle.
- Added ExecutorQueueLimitRejector, SubmitterSchedulerQueueLimitRejector and SchedulerServiceQueueLimitRejector...these classes allow you to wrap an executor or scheduler and track how many tasks have been passed through the limiter, and are waiting for execution to start.  If the queue gets too large this will throw RejectedExecutionExceptions.  This is designed to be a more flexible solution than providing a limit sized queue into java.util.concurrent's schedulers.
- Added ThreadRenamingRunnableWrapper, ThreadRenamingExecutorWrapper, ThreadRenamingSubmitterSchedulerWrapper, and ThreadRenamingSubmitterSchedulerWrapper...these implementations simply rename the thread as configured (either replaced or just prefixed to), and then once execution is complete reset the thread names to what it was originally.
- Some functionality in "PriorityScheduler" has been moved to the "PrioritySchedulerService" interface, so that less will require a handle on the top level reference.
- getScheduledTaskCount() was added to the "SchedulerService" interface.  This was functionality that already existed in the PriorityScheduler, but we wanted to make sure all pools have this easy functionality.
- added getUnsubmittedTaskCount() to ExecutorLimiter so you can know how far back a limiter is
- Added "RunnableCallableAdapter".  This was primarily for internals of threadly, but allows you to convert a runnable into a callable similar to Executors.callable, but this version also implements the RunnableContainer interface
- Small default configuration changes for KeyDistributedExecutor to facilitate better performances for most work loads.
- Interior code improvements to PriorityScheduler
- (Runnable)ListenerHelper now silently ignores invocations to add null listeners
- (Runnable)ListenerHelper now has the ability to return a collection of the currently subscribed listeners
- Added getDelayTillNextTask() into NoThreadScheduler, this is to help allow you to know how long you can block until a task is ready to execute.

Deprecations:
- TestablePriorityScheduler has been deprecated.  It is no longer needed now that TestableScheduler implements the same API.
- KeyDistributedExecutor and KeyDistributedScheduler had api changes...in general "task" was removed from most task submission, "addTask" has been replaced with the more familiar "execute" name
- Deprecated PrioritySchedulerLimiter.  It does not make sense limiting mixed priorities of tasks for reasons I discuss here: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/commit/8ea220cbca0b8530fcf9ebee9be362ac7d025b44 ...As an alternative I recommend wrapping a PriorityScheduler in a PrioritySchedulerWrapper to set a default priority, then put that inside a SchedulerServiceLimiter.
- Renamed "SchedulerInterface" into just "Scheduler" (removing the suffix from all interfaces)
- Renamed (and thus deprecated the old versions) many of the scheduling interfaces:
  - CallableContainerInterface -> CallableContainer
  - RunnableContainerInterface -> RunnableContainer
  - PrioritySchedulerInterface -> PrioritySchedulerService
  - SchedulerServiceInterface -> SchedulerService
  - SubmitterExecutorInterface -> SubmitterExecutor
  - SimpleSchedulerInterface + SubmitterSchedulerInterface -> SubmitterScheduler
  - ExceptionHandlerInterface -> ExceptionHandler
- Renamed (and thus deprecated) PrioritySchedulerWrapper into PrioritySchedulerDefaultPriorityWrapper

name: Threadly Version: 4.2.0
body:
Improvements and changes included in this release:
- Performance improvements in PriorityScheduler and NoThreadScheduler for both scheduled and executed tasks.  This in thanks to pull request #155
- RateLimiterExecutor can now accept fraction of a second permits.  At construction allowing a decimal (for example .5 to allow one permit per two seconds), as well as allowing fractions of a permit at execution time.
- ArgumentVerifier now accepts a double instead of longs for most numeric verifications.
- Improvements to StringUtils (PR #154).  "makeNonNull" was deprecated in favor for "nullToEmpty" and 'randomString" was deprecated in favor for "makeRandomString".  There was additional functionality added as well, most notably padStart and padEnd.

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.1.1
body:
This hot fix release contains some very old bug fixes in the RateLimiterExecutor.  Primarily around handling permit requests which result in less than 1 millisecond delay, as well as calls to get a blocking future.

There was also some minor code cleanup and the added DoNothingRunnable.instance() static function.  Nothing major enough to result in a 4.2.0 release yet.

name: Threadly Version: 4.1.0
body:
Bug fixes and improvements included in this release:
- Added ConcurrentArrayList.trimToSize() to help with controlling memory usage.
- Added ability in profiler to only dump the summary (and not the profile for every thread)
- Added ability to cancel future collections returned from FutureUtils (where you provide a collection of futures and then get a future back with or without results from the futures).
- Minor optimizations in memory usage, FutureUtils, and the Profiler.
- Fixed FutureUtils optimizations that were no longer working like they should
- Fixed defect in Futureutils.blockTillComplete with timeout could throw a NullPointerException

name: Threadly Patch Version: 4.0.1
body: Fixes a small regression introduced into the SettableListenableFuture where a set result may return a null in a .get() call.

name: Threadly Version: 4.0.0
body:
This release includes quite a bit, everything from cleanup, to new and valuable features, to changes in behavior.  I recommend you read the list of changes closely (and file issues if there is any questions).
- Changed PriorityScheduler behavior so that thread quantities are no longer automatically scaled.  Instead the pool is constructed with a flat size (which is still lazily grown to).  The pool size can be changed still at any point during runtime, but it no longer will move between the core and max pool size.  This does NOT effect the ability to change the pool size manually during runtime.  If you wanted to make your own logic to intelligently size the pool this is still possible.
- The above changes made it trivial to fix issue #75 where tasks which have been taken for execution, but not actually executed could not be removed.  Thus allowing a better removal of tasks.
- Because the pool size is no longer dynamic, the behavior of high vs low priority tasks is changed as well.  Now low priority tasks will delay execution if high priority tasks are already waiting (unless they reach their max wait time and are delayed for less than existing high priority tasks).  This continues to ensure that tasks will not be starved, but actually provides a better behavior around low priority tasks (less aggressive).
- Added new "Watchdog" and "WatchdogCache" classs which can watch your futures and insure that they complete.  If futures do not complete in time they are canceled.  Thus allowing for lots of timeout implementations as well as guaranteeing completion.
- Added ability to cancel "SettableListenableFuture"'s.  The cancel will never throw an exception, but will only cancel the future if it has not already completed.  In addition you can now set a thread in the SettableListenableFuture to indicate what thread is doing the processing to generate the result.  With this addition, the cancel has the ability to even issue an interrupt to the processing thread.  Once done, this thread reference is removed.
- "SettableListenableFuture"'s can now be constructed with a boolean to indicate if an IllegalArgumentException should be thrown if a result or failure is set after the future has already completed.  The empty constructor defaults to the old behavior (true, it will be thrown), but you can now control it.
- "SettableListenableFuture"'s setResult and setFailure return a boolean now to indicate if that invocation is what completed the future or not...this may be necessary to take advantage of the above change.
- Added ability to specify a time limit to FutureUtils.blockTillAllComplete and FutureUtils.blockTillAllCompleteOrFirstError
- Added  FutureUtils.makeResultListFuture(Iteratable<ListenableFuture<T>>) which allows you to easily convert a collection of Futures into a collection of results.
- Added FutureUtils.countFuturesWithResult implementation.  This iterates over all the provided futures and checks which one's results match with a .equals() check.  This can be useful for API's which return a failed result rather than throw an exception.  Allowing an easy check to know how many resulted in a given result (failure or not, just an example).
- Added FutureUtils.cancelIncompleteFutures which will iterate over the futures and issue a cancel to any which are not already complete.  Thus ensuring a collection of futures should all be done.
- Added ability to provide a run time in the Profiler when started.  This will stop the profiler at the time point (and complete a future with the dump results at the time of stop).  This can make it safer to expose the profiler and ensure a limited resource usage.
- Exposed constant in Clock class to allow a reference to the minimum accuracy of the clock.
- Removed previously deprecated NoThreadScheduler.tick() which does not have any arguments.  You can simply pass a null in tick now to replicate the old behavior.
- Removed previously deprecated FutureUtils.addCallback (callbacks should just be added directly on the future)
- Removed previously deprecated blocking queue implementation (without replacements): DynamicDelayQueue, DynamicDelayedUpdater, and ConsumerIterator
- Build system improvements, as well as switching from emma to jacoco for code coverage (thus allowing java 8 compiling).

name: Threadly Version: 3.8.0
body:
This will be the last release before 4.0.0!

Changes included in this release:
- Moved AbstractService out of org.threadly.concurrent and into the package org.threadly.util.  We also added a "ServiceInteface" in case you wanted to have an interface extend the ServiceInterface.
- Improved performance with the Profiler, particularly when there is a very large quantity of threads to track.

name: Threadly Version: 3.7.0
body:
The only change in this release is further deprecations of things which will not be supported in 4.0.

Deprecated in the PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker the three functions "getThreadAvailablePercent", "getHighPriorityThreadAvailablePercent" and "getLowPriorityThreadAvailablePercent".  These statistics don't make sense in 4.X because we get the thread/worker BEFORE we get a task.  So even if a worker is not immediately available, that does not mean that a task was waiting for it.  Instead the delay till execution is a better statistic.

name: Threadly Version: 3.6.0
body: This release only includes API changes in PriorityScheduler and PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker to facilitate changes that will occur in 4.0.0.  THERE ARE NO BEHAVIOR CHANGES IN THE SCHEDULER THIS RELEASE.  Instead these are API changes for the behavior changes which will occur in 4.0.0.  In 4.X the PriorityScheduler will no longer automatically scale the thread count between the "core" and "max" count.  Instead it will be constructed with a count, and if you want to adjust it, you must change that set count during runtime (at which point threads will be killed when idle, or created to meet the new set thread goal).  This is still an improvement from java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor, which can not change it's thread count at runtime (despite having the API to do so).  However the change in 4.X will simplify the code, and I am not convinced that the previous feature was not useful to people.

name: Threadly Version: 3.5.0
body:
Changes/improvements included in this release:
- Added "SchedulingUtils" class.  This class provides static implementations to help in calculating the delay for an absolute time (either minute for the current or next our, or a specific hour/minute within the day).  This can be useful when needing to schedule something (likely with scheduleAtFixedRate) to run at a regular time of day.
- Reduced locking in NoThreadScheduler (which improves SingleThreadScheduler as well)
- Added shutdown(Now)AndAwaitTermination feature to SingleThreadScheduler.  This feature allows you to wait till the worker thread joins to the thread issuing the shutdown call (thus ensuring cache coherency)
- Added hasStopped() to "AbstractService".  This will be false while new and while running, it will only transition once stop() or stopIfRunning() has been called (and is running).  This can be used to check the state of services which may be able to accept requests/input before they are running (and ideally would handle those requests once started).
- Fixed issue #130 where worker threads in PriorityScheduler may not exit after a shutdown or shutdownNow call.
- Fixed issue #126 via pull request #128.  This defect in the SingleThreadScheduler would cause it so that if the execution thread was being started while ANOTHER thread was also trying to execute a task, it would get a RejectedExecutionException even though the scheduler had not been shut down.
- Fixed issue where allowing garbage collection of SingleThreadScheduler, PriorityScheduler, PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker, or Profiler....could cause constructed threads to be leaked (and not stopped or collected).  This was fixed first for SingleThreadScheduler which was trivial, but then later fixed for the others in issue #124 and pull request #129
- Updated build system to use gradle 2.3

name: Threadly Version: 3.4.1
body:
We fix two bugs in this release (neither of which were a regression in 3.4.0, but were old bugs):
- Fixed issue where tasks in SimpleSchedulerLimiter or SchedulerServiceLimiter cause scheduled tasks to be run out of order
- Fixed issue in ConcurrentArrayList where we would do an array copy when adding to the end that was not necessary.  This fix provides a performance improvement of about 2% in scheduled tasks in PriorityScheduler, SingleThreadScheduler, and NoThreadScheduler

name: Threadly Version: 3.4.0
body:
This release has a bit more risk (and thus is why it was so slow to be released).  But it also includes some of the most substantial improvements in some time.

Here are changes/improvements included in this release:
- Performance improvements to Profiler when there is a large count of threads to profile.  This can provide a more accurate sample rate when there is a lot of threads.
- Between 5% and 15% performance improvement in the PriorityScheduler due to the pull request #121
- Added "TestablePriorityScheduler"...this is just like "TestableScheduler" except it implements the "PrioritySchedulerInterface".  This is useful for unit testing code which needs to accept that interface.  With that said, this implementation just ignores the "TaskPriroity", since it makes no sense in a single threaded context.
- Deprecated DynamicDelayQueue, DynamicDelayedUpdater, and ConsumerIterator.  These previously were used in the PriorityScheduler, with the performance improvement from #121, they are no longer used.  Because the value to others seems minimal I went ahead and deprecated them to be removed in 4.0.0.  If anyone does in fact want/use these, please file an issue (since there is no available replacement).

name: Threadly Version: 3.3.0
body:
Changelog for this release:
- Fixed defect in PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker where low priority tasks may be too aggressive in getting worker threads when the high priority task queue is running behind schedule.
