This is the same issue as #39.  It was believed that I had correctly ported that fix to the PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker, but I found a one line defect where that was not the case.  There is more unit testing now around this specific case.
- Fixed defect in ExceptionUtils.makeRuntime where the makeRuntime call was included in the stack trace, but the base element was not included. See pull request #119
- Significant performance improvements with the NoThreadScheduler and the SingleThreadSubmitterExecutor!  This is from the two queue method that was developed in #117
- Some small performance improvements to the PriorityScheduler
- Deprecated FutureUtils.addCallback, instead you should just add the callback on the future directly.
- You can now longer scheduleAtFixedRate with a period of zero.  But with that we did fix it where scheduleAtFixedRate can cut in line from other waiting tasks if it is behind schedule (previously it would be like a new exection with a minimum delay of zero, now that delay can be negative to cut in line).  This is why a period of zero is no longer accepted, because in schedulers like NoThreadScheduler that could forever keep no other tasks from running.
- Added ability to clear the result from a SettableListenableFuture.  This was to help assist in some designs where large amounts of futures are being chained together (and thus the result was possibly consuming too much heap).
- Added new class "ChainedRunnableListenableFuture", which allows you to add a Future/callable as a listener and ensure it will execute on the thread pool (even if the future your adding to as a listener has already completed).
- Added new class "ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture".  This takes advantage of the above behavior by clearing the result as soon as .get() is called to get it.  This is obviously only useful in cases where:

1) you need to clear the result to allow garbage collection

....and....

2) the .get() function will only be called once (as subsequent calls will throw an exception).

name: Threadly Version: 3.2.1
body:
This is a patch release with a couple small bug fixes (and one new small feature).  Changes include:
- PriorityScheduler.shutdownNow would not return queued low priority runnables.  This is now fixed so they also are included in the returned list of runnables.
- FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture()'s returned future actually returned an empty list on .get().  This now returns null as previously described in the javadocs
- Added small function FutureUtils.makeCompleteFuture() which accepts a return object, so that you can control what object is returned from .get() when all the futures complete.

name: Threadly Version: 3.2.0
body:
Improvements/fixes included in this release:
- Added ability to NoThreadScheduler and TestableScheduler to pass in an ExceptionHandlerInterface instance to handle any exceptions which occurred on a .tick() call.  Thus allowing you to handle these exceptions, and ensure that the task run count returned from .tick() is accurate.
- Changed PriorityScheduler and SingleThreadScheduler to throw "RejectedExecutionException" instead of "IllegalStateException" when you execute or schedule on a thread pool which has already been shutdown.
- Fixed issue where SingleThreadScheduler would throw exception when attempting to remove a task after shutdown has been called.  We now attempt to remove those provided tasks (as even though shutdown has been called, it may still have a queue of ready to run tasks).

name: Threadly Version: 3.1.0
body:
Improvements and changes included in this release:
- Added scheduleAtFixedRate to the SimpleSchedulerInterface.  This allows you to have a more predictible execution rate, regardless of how long the task actually takes to run.  If a task takes longer to execute than the recurring period, it will NOT execute concurrently.  Instead it will wait till execution finishes, then immediately try to get a thread again to execute again.
- Some performance improvements to the KeyDistributedScheduler when "scheduleAtFixedRate" is called with an initial delay of zero.
- Fixed issue in TestableScheduler where if you advance, or call tick with a faster than real time, and then call ".tick()" it no longer will throw an Exception.  Instead it will tick with the last known time, which will execute anything which has been added to the scheduler with a .execute() since the last tick or advance.
- Expanded Clock functionality to have new functions "forwardProgressing" to get a time in millis since epoc (similar to accurateTimeMillis and lastKnownTimeMillis).  The difference is that if the system clock changes, or is paused, the forwardProgressing time will continue to move forward, and never backwards.
- Used the above Clock functionality to fix issue #109.  This is an issue where moving the clock backwards or forwards might cause a scheduled task to either not execute, or execute early.  The new changes do have some load implications on Windows (though are not ANY slower on linux or OSX).  Though this performance penalty is nothing more than java's built in thread pools.  In fact threadly is still substantially better performing since it has to do fewer time look ups (and instead uses cached values when possible and safe).

name: Threadly Version: 3.0.0
body:
Right on the heels of the 2.6.0 release, we have 3.0.0.  There are no new features in this release, just the removal of the deprecations from the 2.X release versions.  If you are using version 2.6.0 or newer, the transition to 3.0.0 should require no code modifications.

Changes included in this release:
- Removed previously deprecated Clock.accurateTime in favor of the more consistently named Clock.accurateTimeMillis
- Removed previously deprecated org.threadly.concurrent.ListenerHelper in favor of the new implementation at org.threadly.concurrent.event.RunnableListenerHelper
- Removed previously deprecated PriorityScheduledExecutor in favor of the more concisely named "PriorityScheduler"
- Removed previously deprecated PriorityScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper in favor of the more concisely named "PrioritySchedulerServiceWrapper"
- Removed previously deprecated ThrowableSurpressingRunnable in favor of the correctly spelled "ThrowableSuppressingRunnable"
- Removed previously deprecated TaskExecutorDistributor, in favor of the better named KeyDistributedExecutor
- Removed previously deprecated TaskSchedulerDistributor, in favor of the better named KeyDistributedScheduler
- Removed previously deprecated StringUtils.EMPTY (no replacement needed, just use "" which is interned at compile time)

name: Threadly Version: 2.6.0
body:
This will be the last release before releasing the 3.0.0 version!  We plan to release 3.0.0 either on the same day, or shortly after 2.6.0 is released.  If any significant bugs are found, we will release a 2.6.1 patch release, but now new features will be added to the version 2.X line after this release.

This release does include some minor deprecations in the BlockingQueueConsumer, as well as StringUtils.EMPTY.  If you use either of those classes, make sure you are current with this before going to version 3.0.0.

Changes/Improvements included in this release:
- Changed license from LGPL 3 to Mozzila Public License 2.0 (MPL).  This should have less restrictions for others wanting to use our library.  Particularly less restrictions around static linking, or creating fat jars.  The goal of the project is for anyone who wishes (proprietary or not) to be able to use the license, we just want to ensure that changes and improvements get provided back to the community.  If there are restrictions in the MPL that are not conductive to you, please let us know and we will work to make it work for your needs.
- Added new class "AbstractService" to help with building services (either with their own thread, or running on a thread pool).  This provides a small generic implementation for services which have a life cycle of being constructed, started, then stopped.  It is expected that after stopped, they are never restarted.
- Improved performance in PriorityScheduler around low priority tasks.  Specifically avoiding the low priority delay when no threads have been created yet (and thus only a low priority task has been executed).  As well as simplifying the logic when the thread pool has reached the maximum possible thread count (thus also providing some modest speed improvements).
- Other minor speed improvements in PriorityScheduler by simplifying how and when we need to check if worker threads are running (in part facilitated by using the new "AbstractService").
- Dramatic javadoc improvements.  Correctly links to referenced functions/code within the javadocs for easier navigation, as well as a few corrections and clarifications.
- Deprecated StringUtils.EMPTY, a colleague convinced me it is not worth maintaining, so it will be removed in 3.0.0
- Deprecated the maybeStart in BlockingQueueConsumer.  Instead you should pass in the ThreadFactory at construction time, and then call either start() or startIfNotStarted() (depending on the behavior you want).

name: Threadly Version: 2.5.0
body:
This release includes minor changes.  A couple small bug fixes, and a rename of the Task(Executor/Scheduler)Distributor.  Because of that rename, this release includes deprecation of some things, and will be removed in 3.0.0 release.

Changes/Fixes included in this release:
- Renamed TaskExecutorDistributor into KeyDistributedExecutor, and renamed TaskSchedulerDistributor into KeyDistributedScheduler.  The old versions are marked as deprecated in this release (so wont break compatability till 3.0.0).
- Small fix for the rarely used implementations of PrioritySchedulerServiceWrapper and SingleThreadSchedulerService wrapper where invokeAll, after a timeout, may not have canceled all unfinished tasks.  If we were waiting on a task to finish, and we reached our timeout period, that task would not be canceled (but all other tasks would have been canceled).  So this is only an issue when calling invokeAll with a timeout specified (and not all tasks complete that timeout).
- Small fix for the rarely used implementations of PrioritySchedulerServiceWrapper and SingleThreadSchedulerService wrapper where invokeAny would stop invokations after the first failure.  It now respects that if a failure occurs it continues to try further invokations, until all fail (at which point it throws the last ExecutionException it got).

name: Threadly Version: 2.4.0
body:
This includes some additional minor features for threadly.  There were released under the 2.x version branch because there was not a compelling reason to wait till 3.x.

Improvements and fixes included in this release:
- Added ExecuteOnGetFutureTask, this is a unique implementation of FutureTask, where it will begin execution on .get() call if it has not already started in the executor.  Thus trying to provide the result from .get() as quick as possible (and freeing up threads from just needlessly blocking).
- Added ExceptionHandlerInterface to allow threadly to avoid using java's UncaughtExceptionHandler.  Threadly does not allow threads to die from exceptions, and calls info the UncaughtExceptionHandler even when a thread may not die.  This new interface allows you to continue to preserver java's "UncaughtExceptionHandler" behavior, while providing a facility for threadly to notify of when errors occur.
- Fixed bug where exception thrown from UncaughtExceptionHandler can cause a thread to die and be leaked from the PriorityScheduler thread pool
- Small changes around how arguments are verifies.  Making the message in the exceptions more regular.

name: Threadly Version: 2.3.0
body:
This includes more deprecations/changes that will be non-backwards compatible in 3.0.0 release.  In order to ensure a transition with no breakage to 3.0.0 you need to be using this release with no deprecated API's.  This release includes some MINOR bug fixes that are documented below.  It also includes build system improvements (switch to gradle 2.0 and including the gradle wrapper now).

Fixes/Improvements:
- Uses gradle 2.0 to compile now, including the wrapper so gradle no longer has to be manually installed.  Build system is more restrictive on code and errors on more types of warnings.
- Added "ConfigurableThreadFactory"...allowing you to create a ThreadFactory that has the most commonly configured options (thread name prefix, daemon, priority, UncaughtExceptionHandler) easily set.
- Deprecated ThrowableSurpressingRunnable in favor of ThrowableSuppressingRunnable...just a minor spelling correction here.  The old version will be removed in 3.0.0
- Fixed constructor defect in TaskSchedulerDistributor where boolean to track the accurateQueueSize was not respected (in the constructor TaskSchedulerDistributor(int expectedParallism, SimpleSchedulerInterface scheduler,  boolean accurateQueueSize))
- Fixed constructor defect in PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker where boolean for using daemon threads was not respected (in the constructor PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker(int corePoolSize, int maxPoolSize, long keepAliveTimeInMs, TaskPriority defaultPriority, long maxWaitForLowPriorityInMs, boolean useDaemonThreads))
- Fixed issue in ExceptionUtils.handleException where it would not use the threads locally set UncaughtExceptionHandler, and instead would defer directly to the "Thread.getDefaultUncaughtExceptionHandler"

name: Threadly Version: 2.2.0
body:
This release included an expansion of features, with only minor bugs found to be fixed since the last release. The main feature improvements are around making it easier to build event driven listener/callback designs. Part of this release includes deprecation of some things that were renamed (and will be removed in 3.0.0 release).

Changes included in this release:
- Deprecated org.threadly.concurrent.ListenerHelper due to it moving to the new package location: org.threadly.concurrent.event.RunnableListenerHelper.
- Fixed bug in RunnableListenerHelper where listeners could not be removed from a listener that is executing on the same thread as "callListeners"
- Added class "ListenerHelper" as a compliment to RunnableListenerHelper.  RunnableListenerHelper is still focused and designed around notifying events where arguments are not necessary (and thus the Runnable interface can be used).  The new ListenerHelper provides a generic and robust implementation for callbacks which can accept ANY interface, with arguments and possibly multiple functions.  I know the names are somewhat confusing as the old ListenerHelper name has been changed to RunnableListenerHelper, and the "ListenerHelper" is now designed around ANY interface.  But I believe this confusion will be short term, as these names better describe what they are doing now.  If people have recommendations for any name changes, you can always file an issue in github.
- Added a few other classes for handling listeners with different threading possibilities.  "AsyncCallListenerHelper" and "AsyncCallRunnableListenerHelper" will ensure that the call to call the listeners does not block.  These are ideal when there are a LARGE number of listeners, but the listeners are quick to execute.  We also added "DefaultExecutorListenerHelper" and "DefaultExecutorRunnableListenerHelper" add an executor if none was provided when the listener was added, but the submission of the listeners to the executor still occurs on the calling thread.  This has the added feature in that it ensures that any single listener will NOT execute concurrently, despite being submitted to a possibly multi-threaded executor.  This implementation is ideal for when the listeners are very complex/long running.
- Renamed PriorityScheduledExecutor into the more concise and consistent name "PriorityScheduler" (the old version will be removed in 3.0.0)
- Renamed PriorityScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper into the more concise and consistent name "PrioritySchedulerServiceWrapper" (the old version will be removed in 3.0.0)
- More flexible constructor interface for BlockingQueueConsumer (which is backwards compatible obviously, and likely wont be relevant to most people).
- Improved behavior with detecting concurrent modifications in DynamicDelayQueue's ConsumingIterator

name: Threadly Version: 2.1.0
body:
This release includes a few bug fixes that were a bit more involved and harder to split out for a patch release.  It also includes a few new features and improvements around classes/implementations that already exist.

Changes included in this release:
- Added StringUtils class.  This is a simple class that was primarily to make things easier for threadly itself, but may be useful to others.
- Profiler, DebugLogger, and ExceptionUtils now use a system specific line separator.  This is in thanks to StringUtils.
- Added javadocs for many private/protected implementations (to make following the code and extending the library easier)..these are not included in our released javadocs since we only publish the public API.  But these can be easily found with a small tweak to gradle.
- Added shutdownNow functionality to the SingleThreadScheduler (and improved shutdown behavior in SingleThreadScheduler).
- Fixed bug in PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker.shutdownNow where returned runnables are actually the wrappers we use for stat tracking.  We now unwrap those runnables as the interface is expecting.
- Fixed bug in PriorityScheduledExecutor.shutdownNow where the "ShutdownRunnable" may be included in the returned list of canceled runnables.  This runnable is used internally as part of the shutdown process, and so should not have been returned to the user.
- Cleared up difference in behavior with scheduleWithFixedDelay when an exception would occur (in threadly we will continue to run the task, in the implementations of java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService it will stop recurring executions).  This is now consistent with the behavior that both interfaces expect across the board, as well as better documented in the javadocs.

name: Threadly Version: 2.0.1
body:
Patch release to fix issue covered from pull request #90.

Recurring tasks in the NoThreadScheduler and SingleThreadScheduler may end up injecting themselves ahead of other executions that are added while that task is running (either from that task or from other threads).  This is typically only a problem if the recurring task has a delay of zero (so is constantly running).

This patch fixes that issue.  This existed in some form pre 2.0.0, but with the addition of the SingleThreadScheduler in 2.0.0 we now rely on this functionality more, and I felt that it was important to patch.  If your using a pre 2.0.0 NoThreadScheduler with recurring tasks, I recommend you update to this version.

name: Threadly Version: 2.0.0
body:
This release removes previously deprecated API.  In general it is focused around changing things to keep the project maintainable, but does include some new features.
- Cleaned up code, removed things already marked as deprecated
  - Can no longer override done in ListenableFutureTask
  - ListenableFutureResult has been removed (replaced by SettableListenableFuture)
  - getExecutorForKey in TaskExecutorDistributor has been removed (in favor of getSubmitterForKey)
  - Removed constructors that don't accept an existing thread pool/executor in TaskExecutorDistributor and TaskSchedulerDistributor have been removed
  - Functionality in NoThreadScheduler has been moved into "TestableScheduler"...NoThreadScheduler still exists, but it's behavior has been slightly modified (see the javadocs for more details, NoThreadScheduler previously was trying to do both jobs, and did neither well)
  - SchedulerLimiter has been replaced by SimpleSchedulerLimiter and SchedulerServiceLimiter (yes, we are back to two classes for this, since we don't know if we will have service features available)
- Cleaned up unit tests, much much more maintainable for going forward
- Added new interface "SchedulerServiceInterface" which includes things like "isShutdown" (no longer in the SubmitterExecutorInterface), as well as removing tasks.  Most things implement this interface now, giving great functionality when passing around the interfaces.
- Added "RateLimiterExecutor".  This is a new form of limiter, unlike the others which attempt to limit concurrency (for the use of sub pools).  This one is designed to limit the rate of accessing a resource in a non-blocking way.  Please check out the javadocs, and feel free to file an issue if you have any questions.
- Added in "SingleThreadScheduler" to provide a simpler, lighter weight version of a scheduler when only one thread is desired.

name: Threadly Version: 1.3.1
body:
This was a small patch release which fixes issue #85.
Our logic was flipped for checking if we needed to look to add workers when you expand the max pool size.  In addition we had an off by one for adding those workers, as well as prestarting the core threads.  The end result is that a task could be blocked waiting for a worker after the max pool size has been increased.

name: Threadly Version: 1.3.0
body:
This likely will be the last release in the 1.0.0 series.  The only exception would be if any bugs are discovered, in which case a 1.3.1 will be released.  After this release any new features will be in the 2.0.0 line of code.  Improvements/Changes in this release are:
- Slightly more efficient implementation for ListenableFuture's returned from FutureUtils.immediateResultFuture and FutureUtils.immediateFailureFuture
- Reduced code duplication, improved unit tests (though nothing to the degree as what is in the 2.0.0 release) and general small cleanup

name: Threadly Version: 1.2.0
body:
Features/Improvements in the 1.2.0 release:
- Added a feature to FutureUtils, similar to how you used to block till a collection of futures complete.  You can now provided a collection of ListenableFuture's and have a ListenableFuture returned for when all have completed.  This allows you to avoid blocking if you prefer.
- Added FutureCallback, as well as expanded ListenableFuture to allow "FutureCallback" to be added directly on a future.  Since it is often you want the listener to just be called so you know to get a result, the FutureCallback provides an easy way to get the result (or error) directly.
- Added "SameThreadSubmitterExecutor".  A simple executor implementation that will just execute on the existing thread that is providing the task.
- Performance improvements to the TaskExecutorDistributior and the TaskSchedulerDistributor
- Added ability to get the task queue length for a given thread key in the TaskExecutorDistributior/TaskSchedulerDistributor (but you must construct with a true to enable accurate tracking, otherwise it is an extremely rough estimate).
- Fixed issue in PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker where it was not handling the fix for issue #34 correctly
- Renamed "ListenableFutureResult" to "SettableListenableFuture" (since I think this makes it more obvious what it does).  This is backwards compatible, as the old ListenableFutureResult still exists for now, but will be removed in 2.0.0.
- Started marking things as deprecated that will be removed in 2.0.0...see issues set for the 2.0.0 milestone to understand what will be removed

name: Threadly Version: 1.1.0
body:
A small expansion of the feature set is included in this release, luckily no defects found so far from the 1.0.0 release.  Changes include:
- Scheduling on the SchedulerLimiter or the PrioritySchedulerLimiter now has lower overhead. (particularly under low thread pool load conditions).
- Added ListenableFutureResult to allow a simple future to return a single result, possibly a result that was produced over multiple threads or just bit by bit asynchronously.
- Added ListenerHelper to reduce the boiler plate code, and allow you to easily create an object that can register listeners, and then call those listeners when a condition changes.

name: Threadly Version: 1.0.0
body:
Finally the first major release of threadly.  This includes the changes to move to semantic version, as described here: https://github.com/threadly/threadly/wiki/Version-Guide

Because we are trying to get a lot more stable API for the 1.0.0 release we actually ended up changing more than expected.  We focused on simplifying things, and removed a bunch of things we don't think makes sense to support.  We wanted to go ahead and do this now, otherwise we would have to wait till a 2.0.0 release to do these changes.  If for any reason we were incorrect and others found any of the removed features/classes useful, **PLEASE** let us know via an issue so that we can add those features back.

Improvements included in this release:
- Fixed issue #54 where tasks could be blocked indefinitely after increasing the max pool size (under very specific conditions).
- Fixed minor issue where adding or rescheduling a task _may_ be unfairly queued with very large amounts of waiting tasks.  This was an extremely rare race condition, and has not been seen or reported, but was theoretically possible.
- Fixed issue in NoThreadScheduler where you may not be able to remove a recurring task concurrently if the task is currently running.
- Fixed issue in NoThreadScheduler where you can not remove a task if it is submitted from a Limiter.
- Fixed issue in NoThreadScheduler where you can not remove callables.
- Unit test improvements (reliability and code coverage, over 91% coverage now!)
- Lots of javadoc improvements.  Better descriptions, as well as fixes for minor details that were incorrect.
- Improved accuracy for scheduled task execution when there is a very high quantity of tasks, with short scheduled delays.
- Removed the ability to construct a non-thread safe NoThreadScheduler.  If your using the constructor which accepts a boolean, just remove this argument **This is a non-backwards compatible change**.  I did this because I decided to simplify the code and always have the NoThreadScheduler able to accept submission/removal calls from any thread.  So they are always thread safe now.  I figure that the extra overhead of synchronizing is probably minimal in the other case (since the lock should not be under contention).
- Removed the "CallableDistributor".  This was created before Threadly had first class support for futures.  Now that it has full support for futures, you can just use a HashMap, or a blocking queue, or something similar to very easily (and more efficiently) produce the same behavior.  **This is a non backwards compatible change**.  I removed this because now that we have future support, it seemed unlikely anyone would want to use it.  But if anyone likes this feature for some reason please post an issue and let us know (always easy to bring back).
- Removed the TestablePriorityScheduler and infrastructure.  This dramatically simplified and reduced the code.  Because this was very difficult to implement for (any time you do anything that blocks you must consider it), I decided it likely would be too hard for others to use in complicated software.  So I decided to remove it.  **This is a non-backwards compatible change**  The following were removed:
  - **VirtualLock**
  - **VirtualRunnable**
  - **VirtualCallable**
  - **TestablePriorityScheduler**
- Dramatically simplified the limiter implementations, as well as provided performance improvements.  They no longer are dependent on the FutureFuture and FutureListernableFuture implementations which require a future to be provided later.  Instead they just construct a ListernableFutureTask and use that for the entire runnable lifecycle.  This reduced code and simplified a lot of things.  This also allowed us to combine two classes into one.  **This is a non-backwards compatible change** SimpleSchedulerLimiter and SubmitterSchedulerLimiter both combined into a single class "SchedulerLimiter".  This new class only requires a "SimpleSchedulerInterface" implementation at construction.  PrioritySchedulerLimiter's changes are fully backwards compatible.
- Because FutureFuture and FutureListernableFuture are no longer needed within threadly, they were removed.  They are difficult to use correctly (particularly around canceling), and as we found in the Limiter's there was a much simpler implementation once we avoided those classes.  Because we no longer needed them, and because they are likely hard and have little value for everyone else we decided to remove them before the 1.0.0 release **This is a non-backwards compatible change**
- Added call getCurrentRunningCount to the PriorityScheduledExecutor (so you don't have to use the statistic tracker for just this one simple value).
- Renamed The PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker getCurrentlyRunningCount to getCurrentRunningCount **This is a non-backwards compatible change** but should be pretty minor since it only affects people using the statistic tracker, and is a simple two character removal.
- Renamed PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker get[High/Low]PriorityThreadReusePercent to get[High/Low]PriorityThreadAvailablePercent.  The name was missleading to what statistic was really being provided here.  This is how frequently a thread was almost immediately available.  Meaning we did not have to wait for a running task to finish, nor did we have to create a thread.  **This is a non-backwards compatible change** but should be pretty minor since it only affects people using the statistic tracker.
- Added a little utility "AsyncVerifier" in order to assist with verifications in unit tests for operations happening in multiple threads.
- Improved the performance of the TaskExecutorDistributor as described in #56.

name: Threadly Version: 0.9
body:
- Dramatic improvements to the content and formatting of the javadocs.
- Implemented scheduleAtFixedRate in the PriorityScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper.  I was dragging my feet at implementing this because the Threadly design makes this rather inefficient due to gaining efficiency in other areas.  I decided that an inefficient implementation was better than none, so it is now implemented (but be aware that it would be much better to use scheduleWithFixedDelay if possible).
- Added "FutureUtils" class, which right now only has one function basically (to block until a collection of futures all complete).
- Split apart the interface SubmitterSchedulerInterface into a sub interface SubmitterExecutorInterface.  SubmitterSchedulerInterface extends the new interface, so this is a backwards compatible change.
- New class called "ExecutorWrapper" which allows you to turn a simple Executor into an implementation of SubmitterExecutorInterface.
- ExecutorLimiter now implements SubmitterExecutorInterface instead of just Executor now.  This also is a backwards compatible change.
- Improvements and fixes to the PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker
- Improvements to Profiler and unit tests for profiler (but no notable features new features or bug fixes)
- The improvements to the profiler allowed a new class "ControlledThreadProfiler" which allows the user to control exactly which threads should be profiled.

name: Threadly Version: 0.8
body:
Releasing has slowed down slightly as we focus on stability in prep of the 1.0.0 release.

Changes/Features included in 0.8:
- Fixed issue #43, which can cause high cpu usage if a running task thread is interrupted.
- Added a small, and simple call to the PriorityScheduledExecutor so that you can get the qty of waiting, and scheduled tasks.
- Added the ability to make sure that a specific key given to the TaskExecutorDistributor or TaskSchedulerDistributor will not starve other keys if the tasks are given to it faster than it can actually run them.  This comes with some performance hits (but only when using the new optional parameter, and this is of course a backwards compatible change).
- Added a very simple "Profiler" to help in quick debugging of performance issues within your application.  It collects data over time, and returns you information on a per thread basis, as well as the entire VM.
- Moved NoThreadScheduler from package org.threadly.test.concurrent to just org.threadly.concurrent.  This seems to make more sense because I found it has more use in general than just in unit testing.  **This is a non-backwards compatible change**
- NoThreadScheduler now returns ListenableFuture's instead of just basic Future's
- Submitted callables can now be removed from the PriorityScheduledExecutor thread pool
- Tasks submitted through Limiters are now able to be removed from the PriorityScheduledExecutor (but not necessarily other thread pool implementations)
- Up to almost 87% unit test coverage!  This is due to a low amount of code duplication, and really through and complete unit tests.  This number has only gone up between each release, and I plan to keep it very high going forward.

name: Threadly Version: 0.7
body:
- More performance improvements in the PriorityScheduledExecutor and with handling Future's.  This is the best performing threadly release yet.
- Fixed a small issue when constructing a CallableDistributor, TaskSchedulerDistributor, or TaskExecutorDistributor where you construct with a higher parallelism value than the max thread count.  This previously would have thrown an IllegalArgumentException.  This is now fixed (although I will admit that there is limited value in constructing one with a higher parallelism value than the pool's thread count).
- Fixed issue #40 where setting a listener may never complete.
- Fixed/Improved the PriorityScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper implementation to more closely match the java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService definition that Java has defined.
- Fixed a condition when you cancel through a Future returned from a sub pool (aka Limiters), that it may have returned true when it was actually unable to cancel the task.
- Changed PriorityScheduledExecutor shutdown to just stop accepting new tasks, and then shutdown after all tasks have finished.  shutdownNow() has been created which will behave the same as the old shutdown() behavior did.
- General code quality improvements, a little reduced duplication and better unit testing
- Renamed ConcurrentSimpleSchedulerWrapper to ScheduledExecutorServiceWrapper **This is a non-backwards compatible change for anyone dependent on ConcurrentSimpleSchedulerWrapper**....this name makes a lot more sense to me considering what it actually does.
- Cleaned up several public classes which should just have default visibility (should not impact anyone, but if so let me know)
- Moved the Interface for "ConsumerIterator" to a top level class under org.threadly.concurrent.collections instead of hiding it as an inner class to DynamicDelayQueue **This is a non-backwards compatible change for anyone using the ConsumerIterator**

name: Threadly Version: 0.6
body:
Release includes new features and some minor bug fixes:
- Fixed issue #34 where a low qty of low priority tasks could get unfair advantage over large qty's of high priority tasks
- Fixed issue where TaskExecutorDistributor workers may quit with waiting tasks after one of the tasks throws an exception
- Added SimpleSchedulerLimiter to the collection of Limiters
- Expanded TaskSchedulerDistributor and TaskExecutorDistributor, notably to include handling futures now
- Changed SimpleSchedulerInterface to be a ton simpler, and added SubmitterSchedulerInterface which extends SimpleSchedulerInterface **This change is possible to break current implementations depending on SimpleSchedulerInterface**
- Moved Limiters into their own package **This change is also possible to break current implementations dependent on the limiters**
- Moved ListenableFuture into future sub package

name: Threadly Version: 0.5
body:
Small release which contains a few small, but very useful new features.  Changes included in this release are:
- Added ability for threads running in sub pools to be named (so you can understand the division in thread dumps)
- Changed to ListenerFuture, which extends futures but allows for listening for future completion
- Expanded scheduler interfaces to submit runnable with provided result
- Minor performance improvements for code to aid in unit testing

name: Threadly Version: 0.4
body:
This release contained mostly bug fixes. It does provide some small improvements beyond bug fixes though. The bug fixes are listed first, and the additions are at the bottom of the list.
- Fixed rare issue where one task could starve out other tasks in the thread pool.
- Fixed issues with the ConcurrentArrayList Iterator and ListIterator not matching the java.util version exactly
- Fixed ConcurrentArrayList equals and hashCode implementation
- Improved performance of the ConcurrentArrayList in certain situations (addAll operations, repositions which have no effect, etc)
- Implemented invokeAny in ScheduledExecutorService wrapper
- Added PrioritySchedulerStatisticTracker, this class extends PriorityScheduledExecutor, and can be used for troubleshooting and performance tuning when using the PriorityScheduledExecutor. It is not designed to be used in the normal case (although it can be, it just incurs a performance impact), but can be a very valuable tool as a drop in replacement for debugging.
- Added ExecutorLimiter and PrioritySchedulerLimiter so that one thread pool can be used by different areas of code can easily have different levels of concurrency. Thus allowing for greater thread control and better usage of thread pools across your application.

name: Threadly Version: 0.3
body:
This is a pretty dramatic upgrade. It includes a ton of new functionality. It also has a lot of performance improvements and bug fixes. Changes to take note of:
- Removed SynchronizedDynamicDelayQueue implementation and interface...which has been replaced by a completely new implementation just called "DynamicDelayQueue". This implementation is better performing, implements the BlockingQueue interface...I saw no reason to keep the old method, we likely will never need more than one implementation of this type of structure.
- Created a new collection called "ConcurrentArrayList". This is a thread safe array list that is used for the new DynamicDelayQueue. It differers from CopyOnWriteArrayList in that it synchronizes in order to give very strong consistency guarantees. Because of this it is actually able to avoid copies on some operations (and can be better performing). It is particularly better performing when using the reposition operation needed by the DynamicDelayQueue.
- Separated out DynamicDelayQueue and ConcurrentArrayList into a new package org.threadly.concurrent.collections
- Created new abstraction CallableDistributor that makes it easier to submit callables and collect those results. It provides similar functionality as the Futures that are returned from java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService but provide several advantages. First the thread collection the results are easier to make different from the submitter threads (you don't have to pass the futures). The second large advantage is it controls what callables are run in parallel by ensuring that the same keys are never run concurrently, this advantage comes from using the TaskExecutorDistributor.
- Created a StripedLock for the VirtualLocks. This may be useful for anyone who wants to reduce lock contention with our testable VirtualLocks. We are using it to reduce lock contention for the TaskExecutorDistributor and the new CallableDistributor.
- Improved general performance and throughput of the PriorityScheduledExecutor, primarily due to changes with the new DynamicDelayQueue. The largest improvement is in recurring task performance, which has a 10% execution throughput improvement.
- Added in Future support for submitting runnables and callables into PriorityScheduledExecutor (or any SimpleSchedulerInterface implementer). The old calls without future returns still exist because there is a performance impact when using the futures. So this should only be used when it makes sense to do so.
- Increased functionality for TestRunnable class...allowing for asynchronous actions that can be done after runnable starts, but before it finishes.
- Many bugs fixed, and much better unit test coverage compared to 0.2 (82%!)

name: Threadly Version: 0.2
body: Fix from initial release to compile for java 1.5.

name: Threadly Version: 0.1
body: First initial release, showing some of the ideas and foundations for the future of the threadly project.
